awd_titl_txt: Recruiting, Retaining, and Engaging Academically Talented Students from Economically Disadvantaged Groups into a Pathway to Successful Engineering Careers
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, this project will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at University of Puerto Rico Mayaguez.  Throughout its five years, this project will fund 176 scholarships for students who are pursuing bachelor's and master's degrees in engineering.  Scholarships will address college access and economic hardships of target students.  The project includes a research plan to investigate the effectiveness of an institutional intervention model seeking to increase the retention and academic success of talented engineering students coming from economically disadvantaged families.  By leveraging scholarship support and established college-wide programs, the project aims to create an environment that fosters degree attainment by low-income students, in a model that can be used by to other institutions.

The project interventions fit a hybrid theoretical model that combines elements from widely accepted theories on social cognitive career choices and student attrition mitigation.  The longitudinal implementation of interventions will address specific cognitive factors, including sense of belonging, self-efficacy beliefs, career interest, and individual actions leading to the ultimate goal of graduating and inserting scholars into research- or job market-oriented engineering careers.  A mixed-methods research approach will allow for collecting information to assess the impact of each intervention, providing answers to a set of research questions guiding the investigation.  The knowledge gained through this research will provide recommendations for sustainable institutional policies and intervention methods for improving recruitment practices, strengthening retention strategies, and increasing graduation rates of economically disadvantaged students.  The project will foster collaborations among major stakeholders that include academic programs, research centers, faculty, the library, students, and industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project (PEARLS) aimed at improving success indicators among low-income, academically talented engineering students (LIATS). Key indicators included retention, persistence, graduation rates, and time to graduation. The project directly impacted 110 distinct students with scholarships and academic success strategies.  In addition, PEARLS indirectly impacted over 2,000 other students with 43 talks and workshops, 24 semester-long course offerings, and ten community building activities.  PEARLS interventions were designed following a longitudinal, five-stage plan based on the LIAT College Access and Success model (L-CAS), a theoretical framework designed for the project that combined socio-cognitive career theory and institutional interventions to drive students into actions leading to their graduation and professional goals. Results showed significant improvements among participant students compared to engineering peers in the same cohorts, outside the program, including:

  • Retention rates reached 97.1% with respect to 91.9% in the general engineering population.
  • Persistence rates reached 96.2% with respect to 75.0% in the general engineering population.
  • On-time graduation increased by 317.4%, and graduation rates within 150% of the standard time increased by 119.0%.
  • Ninety percent of scholars maintained GPAs above the average of peers in the general engineering student population.

By the project end date, 86.4% of scholars (95/110) had completed graduation requirements while an additional 7.3% (8/110) continued making progress to complete their degrees.  An additional group of 19 non-scholarship students also graduated from the project.  An exit poll among graduating scholars indicated that, by their graduation date, 69.2% had a job secured, 15.4% had been accepted or were applying to graduate school, 12.8% were seeking for a job, and 2.6% were still undecided. Moreover, 81.6% of graduating scholars had GPAs of 3.50/4.00 or higher.

The application of the L-CAS model revealed innovative ways of tailoring institutional interventions to address LIATS’ socio-cognitive factors while incorporating high-impact practices to boost their success indicators. Interventions also helped to narrow the observed socioeconomic status (SES) achievement gap affecting LIATS with respect to that observed within the rest of the students. A total of eight specific areas of knowledge, disseminated in thirteen publications and other formats, resulted from the execution of PEARLS.  These include:

  1. Development of a Theoretical Model to Support LIATS Success: The L-CAS model, with its longitudinal combination of institutional interventions aiming socio-cognitive student factors, demonstrated to be effective in boosting success indicators among LIATS and reducing the socio-economic achievement gap affecting low-income students.
  2. Understanding LIATS Success Expectations: The project provided insights into the success expectations of Hispanic LIATS as they began college. This understanding helped devise effective intervention strategies to boost students' self-efficacy beliefs and outcome expectations.
  3. An Innovative Learning Community Model: A novel model was developed for establishing learning communities among first- and senior-year engineering students. This model boosted career interest, reinforced students' sense of belonging, and highlighted the importance of early courses for later success. Findings indicated that this model improved retention and persistence during the critical adaptation period to college life.
  4. An Effective Cognitive Apprenticeship Framework: A strategy was developed to use a cognitive apprenticeship framework that combined coaching, peer-led team learning, and reflection/self-assessment, to enhance leadership skills among Hispanic LIATS. This approach helped develop leadership competencies and emotional intelligence, influencing students' roles in leadership positions.
  5. A Customized Individual Development Plan Model: Customized individual development plans were introduced among first-year undergraduate students to build career goals and boost self-efficacy beliefs. This strategy was effective in helping students to establish post-graduation objectives and identify steps to achieve them early on.
  6. An Effective Faculty Mentoring Strategy: A successful faculty mentoring strategy was implemented to complement traditional academic counseling. This approach fostered community-building between students and faculty, yielding mutually beneficial outcomes.
  7. Deploying Resiliency and Adaptability Strategies: Strategies were implemented to enhance students' resilience to events like storms, earthquakes, and pandemics, keeping them focused on their studies. Synergy with campus initiatives highlighted the importance of proactive institutional support, offering academic, financial, and socio-emotional services to at-risk students.
  8. An Industry-academia Collaboration Model to Bridge LIATS’ SES Gap: Collaboration with industry partners provided LIATS with eperiences that improved their professional development, leadership, and competitiveness through on-the-job training. This interaction unveiled a model that helped shaping LIATS as future STEM professionals while offering opportunities that contributed to bridge the SES gap that limits their participation in the STEM job market.

In summary, all project objectives were met: improving success statistics among LIATS, boosting graduation rates to produce highly competitive engineering professionals to the STEM workforce and graduate school, devising replicable strategies that can be adopted elsewhere for improving success indicators among LIATS, and disseminating the knowledge generated by the project.

 


Last Modified: 01/01/2025
Modified by: Manuel A Jimenez
